title: Q&A: What are the next steps on the Trump impeachment process?
text:
Didn’t Democrats already say they were engaged in an impeachment investigation?

Yes. Nadler has said repeatedly that he’s been in an impeachment probe, and the Judiciary Committee declared it was engaged in a formal “impeachment investigation” in legal filings in its oversight battles with the Trump administration.

So what’s actually different now?

Nothing and everything. The process of investigating Trump isn’t changing, but it now has the immense power of the speaker behind it. Pelosi has long been an impeachment skeptic, fearful that it might undermine Democrats’ chances in 2020. Now that she’s firmly behind the inquiry, it is far more likely to advance.

Is Trump going to be impeached?

We can’t predict the future, but it sure seems likely. We now count more than 200 Democrats and one independent (Rep. Justin Amash of Michigan) in support of an impeachment inquiry, and those numbers are likely to grow. It’s hard to imagine that those same lawmakers wouldn’t also back articles of impeachment if they reach the floor. A majority of the House, or 218 votes, are required to impeach the president and the math shows where the momentum is.

INTERACTIVE: See where House lawmakers stand on impeachment

Will Trump be removed from office?

If the House does impeach Trump, a two-thirds majority vote in the Senate is required to convict and remove him. At the moment, it seems highly unlikely that roughly 20 Republicans would join all Democrats to do so. But there may be bipartisan concern with Trump’s effort to pressure the Ukrainian president into investigating a potential 2020 rival. And we’re loath to guess the future any more.
